item.title: Skate Season 1 Changes, Cosmetics, and More Detailed by EA
item.content:encoded:
EA has revealed what you can expect from the first season of free-to-play skateboarding sim Skate when it arrives next week, and there are a ton of new cosmetics up for grabs, plus more.

As detailed in a post on the game's official blog, the first season of Skate will bring two seasonal events with it, as well as "a little makeover" for San Vansterdam, lots of new challenges and objectives for you to pursue, and, of course, a brand new battle pass.

First up, it's the first of two seasonal events, Skate-o-Ween. It's San Vansterdam's annual Halloween celebration, but EA says it's "less focused on the spookiness" and "more about getting a chuckle out of someone". It runs from October 21st to November 11th.

The second big event this season is the 7-Ply Maple Harvest, which begins on November 18th and ends on December 2nd. Both events will feature updated community parks, plus new themed cosmetics you can grab either via in-game challenges or by visiting the Extravert Shop.

Completing seasonal events will earn you event currency, and you can then use that currency to grab special cosmetic items. EA says it'll have more info about both events before they go live in Skate.

Season 1 will also bring new general cosmetics for you to earn outside of the specific seasonal events, but of course, the battle pass will have both a free and a premium track, and you'll have to cough up some cash if you want to get premium items.

It's not all about spending money, though; several new music tracks are also being added for Season 1, including the likes of Bad Religion's "Against the Grain", Jane's Addiction's "Stop!", and Gang Starr's "Full Clip", among others.

You can check out Skate for free right now on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox, and its first official season kicks off on October 7th. Be sure to read our very own Andrew's preview of the game to find out his thoughts.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
